<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the pear shaped lute; on which the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-eliz" key="Elizabeth I">Queen</rs> herself once played</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But the Elizabethans themselves are silent. Only their 
            <choice>
              <sic>furni</sic>
              <corr>furniture</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">remains, stiff, ornate, 
            <choice>
              <sic>fasntastic</sic>
              <corr>fantastic</corr>
            </choice> and uncushioned;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the 
            <choice>
              <sic>vardibgalls</sic>
              <corr>vardingales</corr>
            </choice> which roused the preachers wrath.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmy</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">wxmxmxmxmxmxmx The 
            <choice>
              <sic>Elizabthans</sic>
              <corr>Elizabethans</corr>
            </choice> are 
            <choice>
              <sic>unknonw</sic>
              <corr>unknown</corr>
            </choice> to us</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">because when they write 
            <choice>
              <sic>rpose</sic>
              <corr>prose</corr>
            </choice> txxxx the 
            <choice>
              <sic>rhytm</sic>
              <corr>rhythm</corr>
            </choice> of the Bible</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was in their ears. 
            <choice>
              <sic>Its ia</sic>
              <corr>It is a</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>garemt</sic>
              <corr>garment</corr>
            </choice> only to be worn when the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">mind is in the right 
            <choice>
              <sic>attidt de</sic>
              <corr>attitude</corr>
            </choice>. It crushes out the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">simple, the 
            <choice>
              <sic>sublte</sic>
              <corr>subtle</corr>
            </choice>, the 
            <choice>
              <sic>breif</sic>
              <corr>brief</corr>
            </choice>. Their letters are state</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>documnets</sic>
              <corr>documents</corr>
            </choice>, intricate, involved, 
            <choice>
              <sic>circum locutious</sic>
              <corr>circumlocutions</corr>
            </choice>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">There is no gaiety, no freedom, no warmth in the great room.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">When Lady <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-abac" key="Bacon, Anne">Ann Bacon</rs> writes to <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-fbac" key="Bacon, Francis">her son</rs>, she admonishes,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">she 
            <choice>
              <sic>exhosrts</sic>
              <corr>exhorts</corr>
            </choice>. Greek and 
            <choice>
              <sic>atin</sic>
              <corr>Latin</corr>
            </choice> come as easily to her pen</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">as a French phrase would come to ours. If she has to 
            <choice>
              <sic>decsned</sic>
              <corr>descend</corr>
            </choice> to an actual 
            <choice>
              <sic>o jsc t</sic>
              <corr>object</corr>
            </choice>-- a basket of 
            <choice>
              <sic>strwberries</sic>
              <corr>strawberries</corr>
            </choice>-- it w</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is 
            <choice>
              <sic>w   -th</sic>
              <corr>with</corr>
            </choice> dark 
            <choice>
              <sic>insintuations</sic>
              <corr>insinuations</corr>
            </choice>. Fear of God and 
            <choice>
              <sic>suspcicion</sic>
              <corr>suspicion</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of man surround her as with the walls of a dungeon. The wall</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">may conceal a Lady Ann who is merry and gay; it must</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">conceal laughter, love, good humour, and all the trifles</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of daily life. But behind that stiff garment of Elizabethan</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">prose who can tell what emotions are alive? They are</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>pomous</sic>
              <corr>pompous</corr>
            </choice>; they are 
            <choice>
              <sic>solmen</sic>
              <corr>solemn</corr>
            </choice>; they are longwinded;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">We 
            <choice>
              <sic>lknow</sic>
              <corr>know</corr>
            </choice> nothing about the audience who saw the plays acted;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">we know 
            <choice>
              <sic>notning</sic>
              <corr>nothing</corr>
            </choice> about the public who had the books read aloud</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to them.</l>
